comments:
-A lot of new knowledge of classical literature, and a development of a new vocabulary for thinking about literature that I don't think I had before (this developed not by this class alone but throughout the experience of Directed Studies)
-Really enjoyed the essay prompts and think I grew as a writer

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths- seminar discussions were always fun and engaging; I learned a lot. Always got pretty thorough feedback on my essays.
Weaknesses- sometimes felt like a lack of continuity throughout different themes in literature; the sheer pace of the course is overwhelming.

The course was great for introducing students to a lot of important works and ideas. As with all DS courses, however, the speed with which we moved through the material limited our ability to go into great depth or discuss aspects of some texts.
Less reading I guess
This courses strengths are the significant improvements made in students reading and writing ability.

strength: got to read lots of classics, which definitely provides a solid foundation for future literature studies. 
weakness: tried to cover too much.
I think the discussions could be more structured, guided by study questions that pertain to the theme of the book. It's easy to be bogged down by details in DS.

Strengths: 
Very open intellectual environment, controversial opinions more than welcomed
Discussing the Bible as a work of literature with students of different faiths is incredibly fun and a totally new way to look at things
Your writing will improve

Weaknesses: 
Lots of material, very little time: Some works get as little as 75 minutes of attention (waaaay less than time spent reading them) which can be frustrating
Mainly "Western" literature (whatever that means); no Asian or Indian literature

I know there's only so much we can read in a year, but it would be interesting to read some ancient works that aren't Greek or Roman but had a heavy influence in the Western canon, for example: Gilgamesh, the Book of the Dead, Pirkei Avot, the Mahabharata, the Bhagavad-Gita, or the Ramayana. It would also be interesting to read works from the Islamic golden age like the Qur'an and One Thousand and One Nights, or to read non-Italian vernacular works like the Eddas, the Nibelungenlied, Beowulf, or el Cantar de mio Cid.

The readings were really interesting in this class, and Barasch often made interesting points that added to my understanding of the texts. However, we often didn't cover anywhere near the entirety of the text.

I would absolutely recommend this course, especially with Professor Barasch. The method in which we address classic texts allows newcomers and experienced people alike to analyze these texts with completely new takeaways.

An excellent survey of pre-modern literature in the Western canon. Everyone loves DS Lit! For anyone who is worried about the under-representation of women, I think female characters are present and complex in the Odyssey, Sappho, and Greek tragedy -- which together make up about half of our course material -- and there are important moments about women in the Iliad, the Aeneid, the Metamorphoses, the Hebrew Bible, and the Divine Comedy -- rounding out the syllabus. For anyone who is worried about the under-representation of minorities, this is certainly the literature of "the Western world," dominated by Greek, Roman, and Christian perspectives (although the Hebrew Bible is Abrahamic). However, while everything is viewed through that lens, which is often limited, what is viewed through that lens in these texts is often of vast importance to all human experience. Each of these works has something important to offer everyone and cannot be discounted. Furthermore, these books were written in conversation with one another. There is something great to be gained in reading them that way.

This is a good course in which you'll read some of the most important works of literature. However, you definitely have to be prepared to put your own work in, both in reading the texts and thinking about them, since discussions cover so little ground.
Yes
